SECONDARY SCHOOL ENTRANCE
FAILURES
(Educational Facilities)


    3. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Education whether he will make a statement regarding the educational facility for those school-children who failed in the secondary school entrance examination.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Tiong Bahru knows as well as any other Member in this Assembly that the Government's education policy has been to provide free primary education for all those who want it in the proper age group. Those born on 1st January, 1956, or after are within this proper age group and even if they failed the entrance examination, they will be allowed to remain in school for another year.

Column: 1632



    I must stress that the Government cannot afford to provide secondary education for everyone who demands it. However, Government is doing all it can within the limits of possibility to find places for all those who were born between 1st January, 1945 and 1st January. 1946, in other institutions such as the Trade School, Government evening schools, private schools, commercial schools and now afternoon schools. I have evolved a plan to absorb all these children and I hope to finalise all the arrangements by 1st February, 1959. This in effect fulfils Government's declared policy of providing a six-year free primary education as well as keeping off the streets all those children who are 14 or under and all those who failed the recent Government entrance examination in 1958.

SCHOOL ATTENDANCE HARDSHIPS


    4. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware of the hardships of those parents whose children have to attend schools several miles away from their homes, and if he will take steps to alleviate their hardships.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not only aware of the hardships of some parents but also sympathise with those whose children have to attend school several miles away from their homes.

    Every effort has been made to put children in schools nearest their homes but the Member for Tiong Bahru must understand that there are always more children in one area, particularly within the City limits, than there are places in the schools within that area. Inevitably, some children must be posted to schools further away from their homes and every citizen of Singapore who understands the rapid growth of the population in this island must accept this.

TRADE RELATIONS BETWEEN
SINGAPORE AND INDONESIA


    5. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he will make a statement on the present trade relations between Singapore and Indonesia.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, our trade relations with Indonesia are satisfactory and are best reflected in the fact that, despite an eight-cent drop in the average price of rubber, our trade with Indonesia last year, when the final figures are published, is expected to total $1,300 million in value - only one per cent less than in 1957. To have maintained trade at this level in the face of three successive years of lower average rubber prices, namely from 144.16 cents in 1955 down to 96.76 cents, 88.75 and 80.18 cents in 1956, 1957 and 1958 respectively, is, to say the least, remarkably gratifying.

    If we take the available January/November trade figures as a basis for an estimate, we find that in 1958 imports from Indonesia should total approximately $968 million - a shortfall of 12 per cent compared with 1957. However, the actual volume of rubber imported rose to 311,000 tons from 287,000 tons in 1957. Imports of other important produce items such as copra, coffee, tea and pepper tended to fluctuate and may, when final figures are available, be found to have reached slightly lower levels than in 1957.

    On the export side, I am glad to say that final statistics are likely to show that exports to Indonesia last year rose to over $360 million-an increase of 47 per cent over the 1957 figure. Largely responsible were increased exports of rice (up approximately 61,000 tons to 163,000 tons), cotton textiles (up $7.5 million to $20.3 million) and art silk piecegoods (up $44 million to $54.9 million). A number of other export items made smaller but significant gains.

Column: 1634



    Having regard to the comparatively depressed commodity position, this picture is highly satisfactory and reflects the factual state of our trade relations with Indonesia. I may perhaps be pardoned, Sir, if I take this opportunity to state that the level of trade with Indonesia might not have been so satisfactory had it not been for the constant vigilance and assistance of my Ministry, of which the general public is not aware, because we cannot publicise each and every matter we take up or each and every assistance we render.

    I do not think I need dwell on the domestic difficulties in Indonesia. Suffice it to say, my Ministry continues to enjoy friendly official relations and a high degree of consultation with the officials of the Indonesian Consulate-General here, and although we respect Indonesia's logical desire to expand her direct trade connections, we believe that Singapore, as the trade figures tend to bear out, will remain a useful entrepot for Indonesian produce and requirements, and a vital and advantageous link in her external trade economy.

RICE STOCKPILE
(Government Policy)


    6. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he will make a statement on the latest Government policy regarding the rice stockpile.

    7. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he will make a statement on the discussions he has had with the rice merchants and the Singapore Chamber of Commerce about the stockpiling of rice, and whether he will revise the present rice-stockpiling policy of the Government.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, with your permission, I will take Questions 6 and 7 together because both refer to the same subject.

    Representatives of four rice Associations together with representatives of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce saw me on 7th January with a request for unconditional abolition of the stockpile.

    I explained to them that the Government had no desire to carry the burden of the stockpile, but it was necessary in the interest of the general public to have guaranteed supplies in case of any emergency. I asked them for suggestions as

Column: 1636

to any practical alternate machinery that could be devised to meet this difficulty. They saw the necessity for some practical alternate arrangement to meet an emergency but were unable to suggest a solution.

    I then put a suggestion to them that since they claimed that every rice merchant did maintain a certain amount of stock at all times and that since most of their stocks were held in bank go-downs, it could perhaps be a solution if they requested their bankers individually to guarantee to Government to hold on their behalf a minimum specified amount of whole grain rice stocks at all times which will be available to Government on demand at any time. I suggested that such bank guarantees should total to a tonnage of 25,000 tons. This method would not place any additional burden on any of the merchants nor on the public while at the same time ensuring that stocks will be available in an emergency.

    After some discussion, though all were agreed that the suggestion had possibilities in principle, the representatives of the rice Associations desired to discuss further in their own Associations the practical aspects of implementing the suggestion and promised to let me know the results. So far I have not heard from them and therefore I am not able to give any indication at this stage of Government's future policy on the stockpile.

    Hon. Members will of course appreciate that even if my above suggestion is agreed to by the trade, agreement will have to be sought from the Federation Government, as the rice stockpile was set up by joint agreement.

    Mr William Tan: Will the Minister inform the House the total tonnage of the stockpile?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, because the total tonnage is a matter for defence requirement in case of an emergency, I am not in a position to divulge that information to the House.

    Mr William Tan: Sir, the Minister just informed the House that he insisted on a guarantee of a stockpile of 25,000 tons of rice by the rice merchants. Why can he not reveal the figure?

(Statement by the Minister for Commerce and Industry)


10.20 a.m.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Hon. Members will recollect my Written Answer in this House on 3rd December last year on the question of the suspension of imports of certain grades of Chinese textiles. I promised then that I would review this question before the expiry of the three-month period on 27th January as agreed with the Federation Government.

    I may add that the Federation Government appreciate our assistance and have expressed their thanks for our co-operation.
